message: I am humbled and honored to be sworn into my second term serving Connecticut in the U.S. Senate. I am excited and ready to continue fighting for what is right.
I thought my kids were the selfie experts, but Vice President Biden today had a couple tips.

On this first day of my second term, I met with a true hero: Gabby Giffords. Her tireless courage and relentless advocacy remind us that no matter how dark a day, no matter the odds, we can never stop working for a better world—with universal background checks, no gun sales to terrorists, and other commonsense steps against gun violence.

Recent tweets from Donald Trump threatening to sink the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter Program sow uncertainty among our military, our allies, and our dedicated workers who make this next-generation jet. Check out my op-ed in the Hartford Courant on why tampering with this critical program would be a huge mistake.

While this story has a happy, heroic ending, it also reminds us of the dangers posed by large furniture that is inadequately anchored or precariously top-heavy. American families need and deserve a strong furniture stability standard to prevent deadly tip-overs and protect our children.

The latest train derailment in New York should sound a powerful alarm. We can and we must make train travel safer. Life-saving technology known as Positive Train Control prevents disasters like we saw in Brooklyn. This technology is available, and I won’t stop fighting until it is implemented on every track in our country.

There is no question about it: cyberattacks threaten our democracy and our livelihoods. Demeaning and dismissing this blatant fact, as the president-elect has done, is a disservice to the nation and a disrespect for our intelligence community. I look forward to cutting through the noise and discussing real, bipartisan efforts to protect our country at tomorrow’s Senate Armed Services Committee hearing.

My meeting with Senator Sessions today was a very pointed and substantive conversation, which I hope to continue next Tuesday at the hearing. No Cabinet member is more powerful—with more impact on the day to day lives of Americans and more unreviewable discretion—than the Attorney General of the United States. I continue to have concerns about Senator Sessions’ nomination, although I have reached no conclusion as to how I will vote. My concerns relate to whether he will be a champion of constitutional rights and freedoms that are bedrock protections and principles. These rights have never been more threatened, and a champion more necessary.

Cyberwarfare is invisible, but our country is under attack. We are engaged in a cyber war that threatens not only our elections, but our government, electric grid, financial systems, transportation network, even lives. At a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing today, I discussed the critical need for a robust, strong response to recent Russian cyberattacks in order to deter and defend this nation against continuing cyber aggression.

Despite skyrocketing prescription drug prices, Medicare is currently banned from negotiating better drug prices. I introduced legislation today with Senator Amy Klobuchar to end this senseless ban, so we can save seniors and taxpayers billions of dollars.

The anti-choice movement is at overwhelming odds with the American public, but inexplicably Speaker Ryan has decided to double down on the Republican Party’s disgraceful assault on womens’ health. I am appalled by his proposal to slam through legislation that would defund Planned Parenthood and deprive millions of women of access to basic health services. This proposal is especially alarming because it is tied to Republican efforts to strip millions of Americans of their health insurance and gut funding for preventive health care. I ask Speaker Ryan: what will you say to the women and their families who will lose access to safe, affordable and basic healthcare services as a result of your action?

Today’s Fort Lauderdale shooting marks another heartbreaking, horrific tragedy. Senseless gun violence has again claimed innocent lives—travelers on their way to see family, do work or simply enjoy vacation. Enough is enough. This new Congress must act. Our hearts and prayers go out to the loved ones of the victims, and our gratitude to the brave first responders who again answered the call.

House Republicans are back at it. Despite the majority of Americans supporting Planned Parenthood, they are yet again attempting to defund this critical healthcare organization. Their decision to continue these same partisan antics threatens the wellbeing of millions nationwide. In a letter to Speaker Ryan today, I urged him to come to his senses, stop the attack on Planned Parenthood, and put women’s health ahead of scoring political points. #IStandWithPP

It’s simple: No Cabinet nominee should be considered until background examinations and ethics reviews are complete. Without this information, we do not have the facts we need to determine whether a nominee would serve our country—or their own interests. I am calling for a timeout on consideration of nominees until such basic information is available.   https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/ethics-official-warns-against-confirmations-before-reviews-are-complete/2017/01/07/e85a97ee-d348-11e6-9cb0-54ab630851e8_story.html?utm_term=.1f50d0dad2ee

The Affordable Care Act is more than just a law. For millions of Americans, it has been the difference between financial security or bankruptcy. It has been the difference between seeing a doctor at the first signs of disease or waiting until it has spread too far for treatment. It has been the difference – for many – between life and death.    One woman wrote to me that her brother developed cancer when he was just 23. He is one of the 25,000 young people in Connecticut who have been able to stay on their parents’ plan, and thanks to that provision, he received the care he needed without going bankrupt.    I heard from a father whose daughter has Crohn’s disease. He asked me to tell politicians hoping to repeal the law that health insurance is “not a luxury, but a necessity” for his family.    I spoke with a woman who told me that before the ACA, her medications cost $250,000. Thanks to the health reform law, she has affordable health care, no lifetime caps, and knows she won’t be denied coverage because of her pre-existing condition.    As Republicans attempt to repeal ACA, I’ve been searching for how I can best capture what this law means to Americans. It isn’t through a statistic. It isn’t through rhetoric. It’s through you. It’s through these stories you have shared with me about how the law has helped your families. I challenge my colleagues who want to repeal this law to listen to listen to your constituents, and do not deny them health care.

No Cabinet member is more powerful—with more impact on the day to day lives of Americans and more unreviewable discretion—than the Attorney General of the United States. Today’s hearing will provide a critical opportunity to learn more about how Senator Sessions would use this power. I continue to have concerns about whether he will be a champion of the constitutional rights and freedoms that are the bedrock of our democracy. Protecting these rights is critical and we need a champion.

Civilian control of the military is a bedrock principle. At today’s Senate Armed Services Committee hearing, we discussed why this principle is important to our democracy and what circumstances justify a waiver. The standard for an exception is a high one, and General Mattis will need to meet this burden at his nomination hearing later this week. Watch footage of today’s hearing here:

January is National Human Trafficking Awareness Month, and today marks a major victory in the fight against modern-day slavery. For years, Backpage’s adult section has enabled human trafficking by supporting an avenue for violence against women and children. As of today, the adult section is history. I have stood shoulder to shoulder with many of you in the struggle to shut down the section, and this welcome news is a critical step in the effort to end the scourge of human trafficking online. While we have won the battle, the fight continues. We must all work together to end human trafficking.

Today, I asked Senator Sessions: “How can Americans have confidence that you’re going to enforce anti-discrimination laws if you’ve accepted awards from these kinds of groups and associated with these kinds of individuals and you won’t return the awards?”

After reviewing Senator Sessions’ record and reflecting on his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, I have come to the conclusion that I cannot support his nomination to be Attorney General of the United States. At his confirmation hearing, Senator Sessions said simply that he would follow the law. But the Attorney General of the United States must be more than a follower. He must be a leader committed to fighting for civil rights and liberties and the active pursuit of justice.  Senator Sessions has failed to convince me that he will be a champion of constitutional rights: voting rights, women’s health care and privacy rights, and anti-discrimination protections. Rather, he has demonstrated hostility and antipathy – even downright opposition – to these bedrock Constitutional principles. He has prided himself on his vociferous opposition to comprehensive immigration reform – legislation that passed the Senate with 68 bipartisan votes. He staunchly opposed a criminal justice reform bill that has attracted a group of 25 cosponsors, Democrats and Republicans. He even split with the majority of his own party to vote against reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act. Indeed, his career demonstrates a prevailing hostility to the very rights and liberties that the nation’s chief law enforcement officer must always promote and defend. Equally important, I have no confidence he will be the independent, non-political enforcer the nation needs – at a moment when the incoming Administration faces ethical and legal controversies that are unprecedented in scope and scale in our history.

I’m standing with civil rights, immigration, gun control, and women’s health advocates today to say NO to the nomination of Senator Jeff Sessions for Attorney General. At a time when our constitutional rights are increasingly threatened, we need an Attorney General who will be a leader in the pursuit of justice for all. Senator Sessions is not that man.

As Republicans try to strip healthcare from Connecticut families, I am rallying with Senator Chris Murphy, Representative Rosa DeLauro, Representative Joe Courtney, Representative Elizabeth Esty, and hundreds of concerned citizens at the State Capitol to save the #ACA. Since the healthcare law was enacted, the uninsured rate in Connecticut has dropped 34 percent, 1,386,000 people no longer have lifetime limits, 25,000 got to stay on a parent's plan until they were 26 years old, 1,819,938 have access to free preventive services, and 1,554,313 can no longer be discriminated against ‎for a pre-existing condition.   The numbers don’t lie: the Affordable Care Act has made a real difference in the lives of people across our state. We will never stop fighting to protect the health coverage millions of Americans need and deserve.

Today I head back to Washington, DC to continue the fight to save the Affordable Care Act. Thank you to everyone in Connecticut who stood shoulder to shoulder with me at the rally for the #ACA this weekend. And thank you to all who have shared your heartfelt stories about what this critical healthcare law has meant for you and your family. You are the fuel in this fight. You are my inspiration.

Nine of President-Elect Trump’s Cabinet picks have still not completed their required background checks and ethics reviews. This includes Secretary of Education Nominee Betsy DeVos—whose confirmation hearing begins right now.    This basic information is critical to the thorough examination that top-level nominees require and that the American people deserve. We should not be holding any confirmation hearings without it. Just like Trump’s tax returns, I will never stop calling for the facts we need to determine that a nominee will serve our country—not their own interests.   http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/16/politics/ethics-paperwork-missing-for-billionaire-cabinet-picks/index.html

Working hand-in-hand with some of the biggest polluters in our country, Scott Pruitt’s entire career has been antithetical to the mission of the Environmental Protection Agency. And now he is supposed to lead it?   His nomination deserves exacting scrutiny at the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works hearing today.

Representative Price has been nominated to be our nation’s leader in public health. But he has spent his career attacking women’s health. He is vehemently anti-choice, has led the charge to defund Planned Parenthood, and even voted against reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act. How can we trust someone to lead the country’s top health agency when he has shown an utter disregard for half the population’s health; when he has chosen to deny women basic health care screenings, family planning and contraception; when he doesn’t realize women’s health is America’s health?    Price’s extremist views are out of touch with the majority of our country. I strongly oppose his nomination, and I urge my colleagues to do the same.

We all know flying these days is a dismal experience, and American Airlines is seizing the frustration to rake in the cash. It’s offering a “basic economy” fare as a seemingly innovative, less expensive option for customers, but it’s really a cynical ploy to get customers to shell out more for ridiculous fees for basic rights – like simply using the overhead bin. This troublesome trend is taking over the industry, and American’s announcement is the latest in the race to the bottom: squeezing customers into ever-shrinking seats and wringing every dollar from their wallet.

More and more of our nation’s veterans are returning home with injuries that can affect their ability to have children. After a years-long fight, I’m happy to announce that these veterans are now eligible for IVF services through the VA. Expanding access to these life-changing services will help fulfill our duty to care for those who have sacrificed for our country. I will work with Senator Patty Murray to ensure this policy is made permanent and that all those who have sacrificed for our country do not also have to sacrifice their dreams of starting a family.
Guns have absolutely no place in our schools. No one knows this better than the daughter of Sandy Hook School's principal. Thank you to my friend, Erica Lafferty, for sharing your story.

Republicans wouldn’t allow outside witnesses to testify at the hearings for Trump’s nominee to be Health & Human Services Secretary—so today we had our own. We heard from the people who would be harmed by the misguided policies Tom Price supports.    We heard from a 65-year-old retiree who is worried she would not be able to afford to treat her cancer without Medicare. She says Medicare has allowed her to focus on getting better, not worry about going bankrupt. We heard from a young mother whose son was born with multiple congenital birth defects. She credits Medicaid and the ACA for the incredible success her son has had in his journey so far, and says their family would be devastated without them. We heard from a recent college graduate who has depended on the ACA and Planned Parenthood to access the birth control she needs to treat a chronic health condition. She worries what Price would mean for women like her.    These are just a few of the millions of people who would be hurt if Price brings his extreme agenda to the country’s leading health agency. Whether it’s cutting Medicare and Medicaid, defunding Planned Parenthood, or repealing the ACA, these policies have real human consequences.   America, it’s clear: Price is bad for our health.

To all those from Connecticut coming to Washington for the Women’s March, unite with me and other Connecticut marchers outside of the Museum of the American Indian at 9:30am tomorrow before the #womensmarch. #CTStillRevolutionary

Excited to welcome Connecticut marchers to Washington today! Unite with me and other Connecticut marchers at 9:30am outside the Museum of the American Indian before the #womensmarch. #CTStillRevolutionary.

Why do I march? I'm joining my wife, Cynthia, three of our four children, thousands from Connecticut and many more from around the country, to stand and march together for causes and values critical to our nation's future. They are truly American values—like civil rights and liberties, equal justice under law, women's ‎health care, good jobs and economic opportunity for all. They are all threatened. In the tradition of Martin Luther King, whose birthday we just celebrated and whose own march ignited and inspired America, we move forward together in solidarity. Bridging differences of race, religion, gender, national origin, sexual identity, culture, and political affiliation—we raise our voices together in the Capitol's shadow. We know our diversity makes us stronger. I will be asking other Connecticut marchers to give their answers to this same question: Why do we march?

#WhyIMarch?  "We march for the rights of women and to ensure that those in power create laws that protect the right of ALL to 'life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.'"  Catherine and Kate, a mother and daughter from New London

#WhyIMarch  "I am going to Washington DC Saturday supporting the Connecticut chapter in the Women's March on Washington. I am proud to be a part of such a historic event.   I am marching for women's rights and equality. Raising awareness that we get to control our bodies and be the judge and jury for ourselves.  I March for my sisters, cousins, nieces, the LGBT community & friends.  I March for today's women and tomorrow's young girls so the world they inherit is better than today.  I March because our opinions matter and we can make a difference.  I March because I believe in the greater good and the kindness of others.  I March because I am lucky to know some truly fabulous women, who -as role models have taught me to grow and be strong and not back down.  I March for our beautiful planet, healthcare and freedom of the press.  I March for our predecessors that fought for the right to vote and women's rights.  I March for Roe v. Wade.  I March for myself ~ who keeps learning every day ~ who is smart and beautiful, kind and generous and loving.  I March for YOU"  Nancy from Madison, pictured on left with her sister Terri from Clinton on right

#WhyIMarch?  "I am marching along with my husband because it is a pivotal time for women and all those who are marginalized. I march for my biracial daughter in hopes of continuing progress so one day she can be paid the same as a man. So one day the statistic won't be that 1 in 4 women will be sexually assaulted in their lifetime. So that she will grow up in a diverse population where she won't become a statistic but rather part of a thriving community that recognizes and celebrates differences and diversity."  Kelsey, Avon

#WhyIMarch?  “I March to honor and stand on the shoulders of those who spoke up for me and who fought courageously to provide me with the freedoms I hold today. I March with my 11-year-old daughter today to pass on that legacy. Together, we pledge our voices to ensure those freedoms and protections are equitable, just, inclusive and empower ALL people.”   Ingrid, Danbury  Pictured from left to right: Ingrid's friend, Madeline; Ingrid; Ingrid's daughter, Nina; and Ingrid's niece, Emily.
#WhyIMarch?  "We march for gender, racial, and economic equity, and for campaign finance reform, which is at the root of most of our problems."   Women on Watch, Stamford Area

The march yesterday was more than a moment—it has galvanized a movement.‎ Now the real work—and fight—go forward. Let's unite behind the powerful values that brought us to the streets, tap into the passion, and continue marching—every single day.
#WhyIMarch?   "I march as a social work student at UConn, committed to equal rights for all Americans. I march as a woman seeking equal pay and healthcare coverage."  Jean, Old Saybrook

#WhyIMarch?  "I am a single mom and City Councilor from New London, CT! I marched for all people who are still fighting for equality in our great country! For all those who do not feel they have a voice! Change is coming!"  Erica, New London

#WhyIMarch?  “I march for my son who is black, my son who has a disability, my daughters who want pay equity and reproductive rights. I march for you and your children. I march because when one of us is oppressed none of us are free."  Jennifer, Cromwell
#WhyIMarch?  "It's simple: I march for equal rights and dignity for all Americans. And I march to come together and start a movement."  Melissa, Chair of Westport Democratic Town Committee.

#WhyIMarch?  "I march because I simultaneously love America and the privileges it has granted me and I believe it needs improvement; we have never been a perfect country but especially the success President Trump's campaign received whilst targeting marginalized identities is unwelcoming, concerning, and against America's principles of freedom and justice for all. I marched to be part of a legion that believes in progressiveness and gain perspective from other marches while having my own voice heard."  Ashita, Newington, pictured on left
#WhyIMarch?  "To embrace and celebrate diversity."  Yara, Glastonbury

In the past week, bomb threats were called into Jewish Community Centers in Connecticut and at least 16 other states. These threats are insidious and outrageous. I met with Jewish community leaders today in Fairfield County seeking their support for legislation to better deter and punish hate crimes. In the face of intolerance, we must be outspoken and we must be strong.
#WhyIMarch?   "We march for equity in education."  Karen, Amy, and Tina—teachers and education administrators in Hartford and Bristol

I want to thank my colleagues on the Senate Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee for their work last week. At Tuesday night's hearing on the nomination of Betsy DeVos to be Secretary of Education, their pointed questioning exposed her for what she is: unknowledgeable, unprepared and unqualified for this job. She evaded questions about dedicating resources to learning and bringing accountability to schools – but refused to commit to keeping guns out of our classrooms. And the fact that she didn’t even know that the statutory protection regarding discrimination against children with disabilities is a matter of federal law shows you something about her commitment to equal opportunity in education across the country. Her statements at the hearing are backed up by her dismal record in Michigan, where she advocated for an expansion of failing for-profit charter schools that under performed while siphoning money from already underfunded public school systems. Our students deserve better, and as lawmakers, we should demand better. That’s why I’ll be voting against Betsy DeVos.

#WhyIMarch?  "As a mother of two daughters and a disabled son, a woman of color, a daughter, a sister, an aunt, a social worker, a citizen and a human being, I marched to continue the progress for equality, justice, dignity and respect for all so America can live up to the ideals of itself. I stand on the shoulders of those who have come before me and in their honor I am paying it forward."  Dee, Meriden

#WhyIMarch?  "I march because I am a woman. A parent. A member of the LGBTQ community. A student of Social Work attending NYU. A Combat Veteran that has received a Purple Heart. I march because I believe in equality. I march to bring awareness to oppression. To be a voice for those who have been silenced. I march because I believe climate change is real, and want to do what I can to preserve our earth for future generations to come. I march to reject tyranny. I march because I care."  Tamara, Shelton

Voting rights, women’s health care, privacy rights and anti-discrimination protections are under assault from an administration that is demonstrating an antipathy and downright opposition to bedrock Constitutional principles and civil rights. I am honored and humbled to serve as ranking member of the Subcommittee on the Constitution at this critical moment, and vow to use this important post to defend at every opportunity these fundamental rights on which our country was built. I look forward to working with my fellow members of the Judiciary Committee on protecting the constitutional freedoms and civil liberties that have always made America great.

I stood with children and families today to tell President Trump that we are a nation of immigrants – who have helped build and shape America – and his executive orders betray basic American values and our Constitution. The orders take money away from communities, particularly local police, and waste it on a political show project – a wall that only deepens our divisions. Border security must be part of comprehensive immigration reform that also provides a path to earned citizenship for 11 million people who now live in the shadows. We'll win this fight with the faces and voices of children and families like the Al Kalafs, who today told their story of escaping violence and persecution Syria to live in Tolland, Connecticut. Barring refugees like them with a religion-based barrier would be unconstitutional, and unconscionable.
Thinking today of how sad and ashamed my dad would be – a proud American citizen who fled Nazi persecution in 1935 – to see President Trump’s refugee ban based on religious hate and fear.

President Trump’s hateful orders are anti-Muslim, anti-immigrant, and anti-refugee. The only solution is to rip them up. Tonight, I will join refugees, immigrants, concerned citizens, and my fellow Congressional Democrats to call on President Trump to reverse these divisive executive orders. Please come unite with us outside the United States Supreme Court tonight at 6pm or tune into the livestream below.

I have deep, serious concerns about Judge Gorsuch. Whatever his credentials are on paper, most important to me are the real life impacts of his judicial opinions and views. An extreme ideologue on the Court will threaten privacy rights including women’s health care, worker and consumer protections, and public health and safety.   We should strive to insulate the Court from partisan politics – which includes rejecting an ideologically extreme nominee. I have reached no conclusion, but I will support a hearing and a vote. If I conclude that Judge Gorsuch is out of the mainstream, then I will pursue every legal tool available to block his nomination.

The Attorney General must pledge loyalty to the Constitution, not the President – and must be prepared to ensure that the President is never above the law. I cannot assure the people of Connecticut – or the country – that Jeff Sessions would be a vigorous champion of constitutional rights and liberties, and that is why I voted against his nomination before the Judiciary Committee today.

I voted against the nomination of Rex Tillerson to be Secretary of State because of my doubts that he will vigorously enforce sanctions against Russia and Iran or put environmental priorities ahead of oil and gas industry interests. He lacks the experience and the record to provide the crucial advice our demonstrably rash and ill-advised president needs, and to rise to the challenge of representing our nation on the world stage.

On Monday, President Trump signed an Executive Order saying for every new rule a federal agency issues, two existing rules must be repealed. At a Senate hearing yesterday, I explained why this mindless order could have tragic consequences. I shared the story of a three-year-old girl named Brianna. Brianna loved flying kites, dancing constantly, and riding on her grandpa’s shoulders. Her young life was cut short when she was strangled to death by a window covering cord in her family living room. Nearly one child a month dies from dangerous, unregulated window coverings. While we can all agree that we must reduce needless burdens, President Trump’s order completely fails to recognize the life-saving benefits of standards and threatens efforts to keep our children safe from hazards like these. Industry representatives talked a lot about the cost of such standards at yesterday’s hearing. But I had a question for them: What is the cost of a child’s life?
Betsy DeVos is an ethics mess. But don’t take it from me, take it from the former ethics counsels to Presidents Barack Obama and George W. Bush.

The Senate votes tomorrow on whether to confirm Betsy DeVos to be Secretary of Education. The number of calls, emails, and letters to Senate offices in opposition to her nomination has been nothing short of incredible. Over 14,000 people have reached out to my office alone. America, you’ve been clear: DeVos is unknowledgeable, unprepared and unqualified for this job. That’s why Senate Democrats are holding the Floor tonight urging our Republican colleagues to listen to your voices and join us in voting no on Betsy DeVos.

More than 15,000. That is how many letters my office has received from concerned teachers, parents, and students opposing Betsy DeVos for Secretary of Education. This outpouring is unprecedented—and it must not be ignored. Senate Democrats held the Senate Floor all night urging our Republican colleagues to vote no on her nomination. I took with me your outrage, and I shared your concerns about the real threat Betsy DeVos poses to public education, disability rights, and student success.

The Senate votes tomorrow on whether to confirm Senator Jeff Sessions as U.S. Attorney General. Today, I accepted petition signatures from more than one million Americans urging the Senate to reject his nomination. I stand with every American who signed this petition—and the millions more who have taken to the streets to protest, posted their opposition on social media, or called their representatives to share their point of view. I promise to echo their voices through the halls of the U.S. Capitol.

Take note: Republicans did not just attempt to silence Senator Elizabeth Warren last night. They also attempted to silence Coretta Scott King. Mrs. King’s deep concerns about Senator Sessions from 1986 still ring true today, and there is no doubt they deserve a place in this debate. #LetLizSpeak #LetCorettaBeHeard

Our nation’s Attorney General must be an independent legal conscience and a Constitutional champion. Senator Sessions fails to meet this test – instead, his career demonstrates a prevailing hostility to the very rights and liberties that the nation’s chief law enforcement officer must always promote and defend.Yesterday, I received a petition signed by more than one million Americans who objected to Senator Sessions’ his nomination – and there are millions more who have taken to the streets to protest, posted their opposition on social media, or called their representatives to share their point of view. I ask every person who spoke out against this nomination to continue raising their voices when they see injustice – we may have lost this battle, but we cannot be silenced.

Now that the Courts have blocked his unconstitutional executive order, President Trump says he will propose a new travel measure as soon as today. I urge him to abandon any immigration policy that includes religious tests. These ineffective tests only create enemies and make America less safe. Trump must hit reset—not just repackage the same discriminatory order. No updates will fix such a misguided, hurtful ban. The only solution is to rip it up.
Michael Flynn’s resignation was long overdue. Now we need a tough and tenacious investigation into all White House ties to Putin.
Domestic violence survivors who bravely come forward should receive justice, not deportation.
A Day Without Immigrants demonstrates the invaluable contributions immigrants make to our economy and culture.

Now that Scott Pruitt has unfortunately been confirmed, I will fight to hold him accountable despite his plainly unacceptable and hostile policies on the environment. There may not be anyone less qualified to carry out the mission of the Environmental Protection Agency than Scott Pruitt. His record of protecting companies that pollute our air and water and harm our health is antithetical to the purpose of this agency and the priorities of Connecticut families. I will say it again: climate change is real. And it is jeopardizing our safety, destabilizing our ecosystem, and costing local communities and taxpayers more and more of their hard-earned dollars. We literally cannot afford to place someone like Scott Pruitt in charge of protecting our environment.

Even the prospect of mobilizing the National Guard to arrest unauthorized immigrants is truly terrifying for millions of families who have peaceably lived here for decades and call America home. But this proposal should horrify all Americans, no matter who they are or where they were born. Let me be clear: such an extreme action is completely unwarranted, deeply disturbing, and antithetical to our entire system of law enforcement.   Whether or not the White House Press Secretary is telling the truth, the impact of the contradictory messages coming from the White House is undoubtedly already felt by immigrant communities that are living in fear of this White House’s unlawful orders and unwise policies. This Administration's complete disregard for the impact its internal chaos and inability to manage its own message and policy is having on real people's lives is offensive.

We need to get to the bottom of any collusion between Trump officials’ and the Russian government immediately. An independent investigation is critical to determine what General Flynn did, who knew about it, and when. That’s why I led a group of 11 Senators this week in calling on Attorney General Jeff Sessions to appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate possible illegal communications with Russia and any cover-up attempt by the White House. I talked to NPR yesterday about this effort. Listen here:

Internet access can literally be a lifeline for patients—allowing them to connect with family, follow current events and engage with the outside world while they recover. These important contacts can be every bit as therapeutic and beneficial as their medical treatment. I’m grateful that this gap in care will now be remedied, and I thank Secretary Shulkin and Connecticut VA leadership for their swift personal attention to this matter issue and commitment to Connecticut veterans.

The recent surge of bomb threats and hate crimes at Jewish Community Centers across the nation is insidious and outrageous. The Trump Administration must take meaningful steps to address anti-Semitism.

This plan threatens to rip apart families and strip away key legal rights, making us no more safe and betraying American values. Vastly expanded‎ detention likely means a major waste of taxpayer dollars, without measureable benefit. By prioritizing every unauthorized immigrant, this plan effectively prioritizes no one, putting fear-mongering over sound policy and public safety. While I am pleased that DACA is preserved, the parents of Dreamers may be deported en masse, making the relief a mirage. The danger is that these policies will hurt immigrants rather than help Americans.

I will be holding town halls at 1:30pm on Saturday at Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven, and at 1pm on Sunday at Central Connecticut State University in New Britain. I look forward to discussing how we can move our nation forward together and stop President Trump's harmful policies.

Trump promised on the campaign trail to reign in prescription drug prices. But just weeks into his presidency, Trump is already sending contradictory signals on that commitment. Today I heard from families in Connecticut who struggle to afford prescription drugs and doctors who see firsthand how high drug prices compromise care. I am advocating for measures to reign in prescription drugs prices and ensure every American can afford the medicines they need. If Trump wants to make good on his campaign promise, I challenge him to support them.

More than 900 people died from drug overdoses in Connecticut last year. Today I heard from recovering addicts who are in treatment thanks to the Affordable Care Act. Repealing this critical healthcare law would pull the rug out from under local communities working to combat the opioid epidemic and leave millions of Americans seeking treatment without a place to turn.
Reminder that I am holding a town hall tomorrow at 1:30pm at Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven. Hope to see you there!
I am holding a town hall in New Haven right now at Wilbur Cross High School. If you couldn't make it, tune into the livestream here: http://wtnh.com/on-air/watch-us-live-breaking-now/

Eighteen-year-old Ashley Parnam was picking up her little brother from football practice when she got into a fender bender in the parking lot. What should have been a minor crash turned deadly when the Takata airbag in her car exploded violently sending shrapnel everywhere—killing her within minutes. She is one of eleven people who have died as a result of Takata’s defective airbags. Nearly two hundred others have been injured – wounding limbs, suffering terrible facial lacerations, or losing their sight. Marian Anderson, who lived in Danbury, worked through poverty and racial discrimination to become the first African American to perform with the Metropolitan Opera. When she was barred from performing at a segregated concert venue in D.C. in 1939, she performed instead on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial. Her concert drew an integrated crowd of 75,000 people to the National Mall—sparking a national debate surrounding segregation and racial prejudice. Her performance of “My Country Tis of Thee” that day became an anthem for the emerging civil rights movement.    "The knowledge of the feelings other people have expended on me has kept me going when times were hard. That knowledge has been a responsibility, a challenge and an inspiration. It has been the path to development and growth. The faith and confidence of others in me have been like shining, guiding stars."   Photo Credit: Library of Congress

Ella Tambussi Grasso, born in Windsor Locks, devoted her life to public service. Following her election to the General Assembly in 1952, she never lost a race in her 28-year career. There can be no delay.

These are not the words of a man with nothing to hide or nothing to fear. Time for answers and accountability.
The Art of the Steal: Trump's reverse Robin Hood budget rips off America's most vulnerable - all to enrich people like him.

President Trump’s budget is absolutely stunning in its cruelty. It is a gigantic bait and switch - betraying his campaign promises by giving humongous benefits to the wealthy and the back of the hand to the most vulnerable Americans.   But this budget is not only cruel - it’s counterproductive. It fails to recognize that our national security involves more than just military spending - it is the health of our children, the education of our workforce, and the strength of our transportation network. The budget undercuts our defense industrial base by failing to invest in skill training. And by decimating domestic programs, it will simply make us less safe.   Most obviously, President Trump’s promised $1 trillion infrastructure plan is ominously missing. Instead, he eliminates programs that support millions of jobs in Connecticut and across the country while leaving our bridges and roads to crumble in disrepair.   This budget also opens another front in the war on women’s health and the assault on Planned Parenthood, which provides preventive care for women and men who desperately need it. And it undercuts research at the NIH, disease prevention at the CDC, mental health, and other vital health care efforts.

Today’s CBO score puts in stark terms what a horror show the House Republicans’ healthcare plan would be for American families. The score shows skyrocketing financial costs, catastrophic human costs, and unconscionable moral costs.  This heartless House healthcare plan is dead on arrival - zero pulse.

As we head into Memorial Day weekend - the unofficial start of summer - I joined my colleagues on the Senate Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection to discuss pool safety and the dangers of drain entrapment. We have made much progress in the ten years since the Virginia Graeme Baker Pool and Spa Safety Act, but the law still doesn’t cover 97% of pools in the United States, including residential pools and spas. Dangerous drains can lead to serious injury or deadly entrapment. Meanwhile, drowning remains the leading cause of accidental death among children ages 1 to 4, and the #2 cause among children ages 5 to 14.   I want to thank all of the panelists for adding their perspectives to this important conversation, especially Connecticut’s own Karen Cohn. Karen co-founded the ZAC Foundation with her husband Brian in honor of their 6-year-old son Zachary, who passed away after being entrapped by a drain. With summer nearly here, please take a minute to familiarize yourself with these lifesaving pool safety tips.

Only someone with secrets would want a secret and private line to Vladimir Putin. Jared Kushner owes America an immediate explanation.

It was my pleasure to join Mayor Rilling and Acting Chief Gatto to announce well-deserved federal funding for the Norwalk Fire Department. No one can fight and win if they abandon the field. America has been made a lesser nation by withdrawing from the Paris Agreement: in jobs and technology, in innovation and leadership, in saving our planet and rolling back the progress we’ve made in combating climate change.  America will regret relinquishing leadership and carelessly abandoning a commitment that would make our country greater. The looming disaster of climate change is now on the shoulders of those in the Trump Administration who have undermined our credibility around the world and jeopardized the safety and prosperity of future generations.
Proud to #WearOrange alongside these tireless advocates in Stamford. Together, we will combat the senseless scourge of gun violence.

I joined the Newtown #WearOrange march in memory of the thousands of lives cut short by gun violence every year - and in solidarity with the survivors who bear its scars and families who mourn lost loved ones every day.  We must redouble our efforts to stem the terrible tide of gun violence that touches communities of all sizes and Americans from all walks of life. It’s long past time to embrace commonsense solutions and reject cowardly excuses.
Nationwide air traffic control privatization would be a huge giveaway to airlines - and an awful deal for consumers.
73 years ago, Allied troops stormed Normandy's beaches and forever changed the course of history. Today and every day, we salute them.

On this day 52 years ago, the Supreme Court issued its historic ruling in the case of Griswold v. Connecticut – a game changer that paved the way for increased access to contraception.  Yet despite decades of profound progress since June 7, 1965, many remain desperate to turn back the clock on women’s ability to make their own healthcare decisions. From federal and state attempts to defund Planned Parenthood to withering attacks on the Affordable Care Act’s birth control coverage mandate, the stakes in this ongoing fight couldn’t be higher.  I am more committed than ever to resisting any and all retrograde attacks on women's health. We’ve come too far to let anyone take us back.

I was in the room for all of Jim Comey’s riveting testimony today. I watched him paint a chilling portrait of a president abusing his power and seeking to put himself above the law – from urging the FBI to shut down its Flynn investigation to demanding loyalty from its leader. Special Prosecutor Mueller now has even more evidence to investigate and consider as he determines whether obstruction of justice charges are warranted.   We learned a lot today, but questions about the roles of many key actors remain unanswered. Attorney General Sessions and Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein must be called to testify before the Judiciary Committee under oath and in public. They must answer for their abject failure to safeguard the independence of the FBI and stand up to a president who sought to intimidate it into submission.   In the meantime, the investigation of Russian meddling in our democracy must have the resources and independence to continue. Uncovering and punishing all lawbreakers, as well as everyone who aided and abetted them, is our only hope of preventing interference in future elections. We must act as if our very independence as a nation is at stake – because it is.

As America marks one year since the Pulse nightclub tragedy in Orlando, we must recommit to disarming hate and fighting for commonsense measures to keep firearms away from potential terrorists and dangerous individuals.  Each day that passes without action is a threat to communities large and small, an affront to those touched by gun violence, and a betrayal to American values.

Today’s Ninth Circuit ruling against President Trump’s Muslim ban is not just a welcome defeat for one of this administration’s most atrocious acts. It is an essential reminder that even the President is not above the law – and that consequences will follow when actions exceed the scope of his authority.

My heart goes out to Congressman Scalise, his staff, and the security officials involved in this horrific shooting. I am especially grateful this morning for the swift action of the Capitol Police, who unhesitatingly disregarded danger to themselves in protecting others. I am hopeful we can put aside politics and support all affected.

There is no state or town immune to America’s opioid epidemic. Battling this devastating public health crisis is hard enough as it is – but if Republicans had their way, the Medicaid expansion that has helped so many receive treatment would be ripped apart. We must embrace every tool at our disposal to defeat the deadly grip of opioids, not weaken a vital lifeline for communities that need it most.
Standing-room only at this morning's healthcare hearing in Hartford. With energy like this, no wonder Republicans are terrified of showing America their bill.

The Constitution’s Foreign Emoluments Clause is very clear: Presidents must seek and obtain Congressional consent before accepting any gifts, payments, or benefits from foreign states. President Trump’s failure to follow this essential anti-corruption requirement deprives Congress of the chance to consent, leaving us no choice but to take action.  That’s why I’m leading nearly 200 members of Congress – from the Senate and House – in demanding the courts act to protect the Constitution. No American is above the law, not even the President.

My constituents are right: Lives and health are at stake if Republicans succeed in gutting the Affordable Care Act. They are the reason I’ll never back down.

Senate Republicans made mere cosmetic changes to the House’s cruel and costly healthcare bill, but their nips and tucks aren’t nearly enough to reshape this reprehensible plan into anything approaching responsible legislation. Countless Connecticut patients – and millions more across America – will lose access to critical healthcare services and protections. It is not an overstatement to say that the Republicans’ plan will literally cost American lives.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Thirteen Republican men worked behind closed doors to craft a bill that defunds Planned Parenthood and blocks women and men from accessing basic healthcare services offered at these clinics. It is a slap in the face to every American who has sought family planning services, cancer screenings or basic healthcare from the provider they trust. The bill guts Medicaid – throwing children and families who rely on it to the wolves. Seniors will see skyrocketing costs, if they are able to receive coverage at all under this heartless plan. And while the opioid crisis ravages communities in every corner of the country, this bill woefully underfunds programs for drug treatment and recovery.   In short, this bill would decimate my constituents’ ability to access the care they need and deserve. I pledge to fight  to make sure this disgraceful excuse for reform never passes the Senate.

So many constituents spoke out powerfully about the GOP’s heartless and harmful healthcare bill at our packed field hearing today in New Haven.  I'm so grateful for all who attended, and honored to stand up for you in the Senate.

Today's delayed healthcare vote is a powerful testament to millions of Americans who stood up and spoke out against this bill’s cruel and costly inhumanity. Thanks to the faces and voices of ordinary Americans, this wealthcare proposal has been stopped – for now.  We have won a reprieve more than a victory – and there is no time for complacency. This titanic fight for the American healthcare system is far from over.

There is something fundamentally wrong with a system that incentivizes mass incarceration, but that’s exactly what we have in the United States of America. Current sentencing guidelines have handed millions of people – a disproportionate number of them people of color – harsh prison sentences. Their lives have been irreparably altered, and our communities are no safer for it.   That’s why I am proud to partner with Sen. Cory Booker on the Reverse Mass Incarceration Act. This bill would create new incentives for states that decrease incarceration while keeping down crime. I am hopeful that my colleagues will join us and address the crisis of mass incarceration with the urgency it demands.

The Trump Administration's travel ban rules effectively disregard and distort the Supreme Court’s order, rejecting lawful immigrants and refugees with bona fide ties to the United States.   The Administration intends to turn away tens of thousands of refugees who already have an ongoing relationship with a U.S. resettlement agency under contract with our government working to bring them here. Such refugees have already undergone extensive vetting and have a close connection with a U.S. government-approved organization which can vouch for them. They are, in short, exactly the kind of individuals who are protected by the Supreme Court’s order earlier this week, which strikes down the ban for all refugees with a ‘credible claim’ to a legitimate relationship with individuals or entities here.   The Administration is turning away Americans’ family members in direct and clear violation of the Supreme Court’s order. To take just one example, the State Department has said it will not provide visas to the fiancés of U.S. citizens if they would be blocked by the Executive Order, even though the Supreme Court said explicitly that fiancés are protected.  Once again, the Trump Administration is preparing to roll out a travel ban with no consultation and minimal forethought and respect for the law. Once again, the travel ban clearly violates the law – in this case a Supreme Court opinion that is less than a week old. Donald Trump must recognize that he is not above the law.
My sincere thanks to all who joined and shared their stories at today's emergency healthcare field hearing in Hartford.

This afternoon I stopped by Connecticut Children's Medical Center to highlight the dangers of hot cars.  On average, 37 kids in the United States die of heatstroke in hot cars every year. Tragedy can strike year-round; car interiors can reach 110 degrees even when outside temperatures are in the 60s. Heat stroke can occur in 57 degree weather.   The most important thing a parent or caregiver can do is to Look Before You Lock - taking an extra second to make sure your child is not left behind.    We all have a role to play in preventing these tragedies. That's why I am leading legislation in the Senate to require car makers to install rear seat sensors - a technology that already exists but is not in widespread use.  Together, we can make this summer safer for the whole family.

The urgent danger to the American mainland posed by North Korea’s nuclear program requires an immediate strategy from the Trump Administration to stop it. Time is not on our side. The President must present a clear and comprehensive strategy using economic sanctions, diplomacy, and credible military capability to deter North Korea and engage China.   Any talks with North Korea must be conditioned on verifying through the IAEA that their nuclear weapons program is suspended. History shows that the North Koreans use negotiations as a cover for covert nuclear weapons efforts, violating and exploiting even temporary agreements. In the meantime, sanctions can be effective if intensified and targeted at energy and fuel sectors as well as military products.

I’m so grateful to everyone who attended and spoke out at tonight’s emergency healthcare field hearing in West Hartford. It’s my honor and privilege to ensure your stories are heard in this titanic fight for our nation’s healthcare system.
Sen. Chris Murphy and I agree: Mend the Affordable Care Act – don't end it. Constituents deserve bipartisan reform that puts their needs and concerns first.

Trumpcare 3.0 is an abomination to anyone who cares about the future of healthcare in the United States of America.  This bill decimates Medicaid through devastating cuts that would disproportionately affect the most vulnerable Americans: working class families, sick children, and the elderly. Millions of Americans would be forced to live with the completely inadequate, second-class coverage proposed by this bill – a plan that would further sabotage the healthcare exchanges and fracture the markets. Basic, preventative healthcare coverage, including maternity care and mental healthcare, would be jeopardized by this bill. Planned Parenthood, a health provider that brings millions of women and men both care and peace of mind, would be cruelly defunded for political purposes.  In the long run, the ramifications of this bill would be not only cruel, but incredibly costly for the American public. We in Congress have the opportunity and the obligation to expand the Affordable Care Act.  This latest iteration of a Republican healthcare proposal does nothing but take us backwards.
A little rain won’t get in the way of LEAP’s 2017 “Read-In on the Green” in New Haven! It was such a joy to meet these students at Clinton Avenue School this morning.
Thanks to all who joined for today's healthcare field hearing. The voices and stories I heard in New London will be heard in Washington.

Thanks to the passion and persistence of Americans across the country, we now have a historic opportunity to come together to improve healthcare for millions of Americans – but only if Republican leaders abandon their cruel and costly campaign to repeal the Affordable Care Act and decimate Medicaid.  If Republicans go back to the drawing board and commit to improving the Affordable Care Act – not destroying it – they will find eager partners across the aisle. If their version of starting from scratch is a repeal of the Affordable Care Act, they will find the same popular outrage and outcry that doomed their wealthcare plan.  Continued repeal posturing is a deceptive, destructive charade. Let’s come together to lower the cost of healthcare, cut costs of pharmaceutical drugs, increase consumer choices, and take other steps to enhance access and affordability. Republicans should join us immediately to support the exchanges and stop sabotaging them.

Stunning revelations about meetings between Trump campaign members and Russian agents – another tile in the mosaic to be pieced together by federal investigators, congressional committees and special counsel Mueller – have made the need for increased Russian sanctions clearer than ever.

I opposed the nomination of Jeff Sessions, but the Attorney General should not be forced to resign for doing the right thing – following ethical rules and upholding the rule of law – especially if he will be replaced by a politically compliant lackey handpicked by President Trump. The Attorney General of the United States should be a watchdog, not a lapdog.  This issue is ultimately not about Jeff Sessions; it’s about the rule of law. The most important priority now is to protect the independence and integrity of Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation against the renewed threat of political interference from President Trump, which again has raised the specter of obstruction of justice. The investigation has now expanded appropriately to include relevant Trump financial dealings. Attempts by the President to set limits on the investigation are inappropriate and potentially illegal.

Americans deserve A Better Deal because right now they’re getting stuck with a raw deal. While millions struggle every day to make ends meet and avoid falling behind, Washington seems to serve only the wealthy and well-connected.   The hardworking people of this great country deserve leadership that puts their priorities front and center - higher wages, better education, and an economy that works for everyone. Servicemembers should be accepted on the basis of their ability to fight, train, and deploy without discrimination. Many transgender Americans have served honorably and capably - and countless others are serving now and would seek to serve in the future.  President Trump should be thanking these servicemembers and veterans for their dedication and commitment to our nation instead of barring them from service. This rash and surprising Tweet contradicts the Department of Defense’s previous policy decision to allow transgender servicemembers to serve openly, and constitutes official discrimination.

This afternoon I met with chefs and food policy advocates to discuss the Food Recovery Act, which I am introducing with Rep. Pingree. This bill would address inefficiencies that lead to waste across all aspects of the food supply chain – curbing the 62 million tons of food thrown out each year in the United States.    Simplifying food date labeling and diverting healthy, wholesome food from landfills won’t just benefit the environment – it will help alleviate food insecurity and save consumers and businesses money. I urge my colleagues to join us and tackle the challenge of food waste with the multifaceted response it demands.
With the Senate healthcare vote looming, your pressure has never been more important. Thank you to all who have spoken out and continue to do so.
We owe it to the American people to reject “skinny repeal” – a sham reform that will drive up costs and eliminate coverage for millions.

Tonight’s vote is a testament to the millions of Americans who never gave up - who relentlessly spoke out and stood up with caring and conviction. They came to town halls, called Congress, and posted on Facebook.  It is also a tribute to the Senators who heard those voices, and put the people they represent first. A few profiles in ‎courage slowed - and maybe stopped – a tragic assault on American healthcare. Being in the Senate Chamber for this vote was a proud and moving moment.  We must now come together, reaching across partisan divides. Let us end a misguided and misanthropic effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act. We stand ready to work on commonsense, bipartisan improvements to our healthcare system, joining our colleagues across the aisle.

I am relieved today, but make no mistake - this is not the end of the fight for healthcare. There is still so much on the line for millions of Americans, including hundreds of thousands in Connecticut.  We all have a role to play in what comes next. Let's keep pushing for the solutions we need and a bipartisan process we can all be proud of.
No more excuses. With passenger safety at stake, FAA cannot sit back and ignore cramped conditions in our skies.

Back-seat alerts could save the lives of dozens of children killed tragically in overheated cars each year, but this simple solution has yet to see widespread use.  That’s why today, on National Heatstroke Prevention Day, I am proud to introduce the HOT CARS Act with Sen. Franken. This bill would ensure back-seat sensor technology is available in every car sold in the United States. Combined with public awareness and vigilance, we can prevent these catastrophes and save lives.

President Trump’s signing of strict sanctions legislation is a major step toward holding Russia, North Korea, and Iran accountable – but it cannot be the last. Vigorous enforcement of this law must follow to ensure rogue regimes pay a painful price for their persistent and destabilizing actions.  President Trump must send a strong signal that America will not accept any attempts to subvert global security and order.

The unanimous passage of this comprehensive GI Bill reform legislation is a great victory for our student veterans and their family members. This bill will ensure the protection and expansion of critical veterans’ education benefits to reservists, surviving family members, and Purple Heart recipients, in addition to restoring education benefits to student veterans who lost entitlement after recent school closures.  The reclaiming of education benefits will make a world of difference for student veterans, enabling them to more smoothly transition into civilian life and achieve their educational goals.

The Special Counsel Independence Protection Act seeks to forestall a potential constitutional crisis raised by President Trump’s ominous ongoing threats of improperly firing the current special counsel. The specter of Presidential action against Robert Mueller – designed to stop or stymie a vitally necessary criminal investigation of the President himself – makes safeguarding the special counsel urgently necessary.  Congress must act, right away, to check this potential Presidential abuse of power. Even the threat of such political interference, constituting potential obstruction of justice, undermines the special counsel’s investigation. Only judicial review can check such possible abuse and eliminate any doubt about special counsel’s ability to hold accountable all lawbreakers.  Make no mistake: this investigation will continue and conclude fairly and fully.

President Trump's words today were nothing more than a dog whistle to the people whose hateful ideologies spurred violence that left one dead and many more injured. Our leaders must condemn hate and bigotry in no uncertain terms, consistently, repeatedly and unequivocally. President Trump’s failure to specifically denounce the racist, bigoted, white supremacist groups who organized today’s rally speaks volumes. Hate and violence have no place in our democracy. I stand with all Americans against today's disgusting display of bigotry. That is not who we are.

Today we mark five years since the implementation of DACA, a lifeline for thousands of young people in Connecticut and nearly one million nationwide. DACA allows many of America’s best and brightest to follow their dreams and give back to the only home they know - free from the specter of deportation. That cannot change.   Now more than ever, we must recommit to defending this vital program - and redouble our fight for immigration reform that is comprehensive, lasting, and fair.

My dad came to America in 1935 to escape Nazi Germany. He was 17 years old, had little more than the shirt on his back, spoke virtually no English, and knew almost no one. But this great country – the greatest in the world – gave him a chance to succeed and raise a family. No one loved this country more than him.   Over the last few days, I’ve thought about how sad and ashamed he would be to see the images out of Charlottesville – and to watch a President condone the torch-carrying, epithet-shouting, hate-filled people who rallied in its streets.   We are at a critical juncture in American history. Now is the time for everyone who believes in the promise of America to unite and speak out in defense of our values. Silence is not golden. Ambiguity is abhorrent. We must condemn the false moral equivalency that President Trump suggested on Saturday and doubled down on yesterday.   Both sides are not to blame. One side is to blame.

The lethal domestic terror in Charlottesville was bigger than just one man. That’s why I’m urging Attorney General Sessions to expand the Justice Department’s investigation to include the extremist groups involved in Saturday’s violence.  Any probe that places blame on one individual ignores the reality of what our nation witnessed. The white supremacist groups that fomented and facilitated this violence must be held to task.

This morning in Bridgeport, I heard from participants and host agencies about how the MaturityWorks program equips older Americans with the skills training they need to find and keep jobs.  Funding for Labor Department training programs like MaturityWorks would disappear in the Trump budget. Older Americans - in Connecticut and nationwide - deserve better.
What a comeback by Fairfield American in the Little League World Series. So proud of you all – good luck tonight!

The President seems to be deepening U.S. involvement in Afghanistan, and increasing troop levels, without a clear, specific strategy. This supposed new policy is vague and open ended. More details with defined achievable objectives are essential.  Military force without forceful, effective diplomacy is no strategy. In Afghanistan and around the world, we must defeat terrorists and prevent attacks on our nation by denying them bases and safe havens. Afghanistan must be made secure militarily, and its government must be made more capable and less corrupt. An effective strategy requires a robust State Department, and economic and humanitarian support.  Our priority goal must be America’s own security. We must defeat terrorism, and prevent terrorist attacks on our nation, but Americans deserve to know how that will be actually accomplished and measured.
Another impressive victory for Fairfield American at the Little League World Series. On to the semifinals!

George Michael Bekech of Trumbull exemplifies the Greatest Generation. As a nose gunner in the 376th Bombardment Group during World War II, he flew 49 missions and stared down some of the greatest evils the world has ever seen.    It was a tremendous honor to present an American flag that was recently flown over the Capitol building to this living legend today. We must never forget the enormous debt we owe to heroes like Mr. Bekech, whose inspiring service and incredible sacrifice stand as testaments to the indomitable American spirit.

I am so proud to stand with Americares and support the tireless work they are doing in the wake of Hurricane Harvey – an ongoing humanitarian crisis that is expected to cause untold suffering across the Gulf Cost.   This disaster is an opportunity for us to unite and support Gulf Coast communities when they need it most, and I urge all Connecticut residents to lend whatever help they can to relief efforts like Americares.    I will return to Congress and press my colleagues to approve all necessary relief for the Gulf Coast to recover from this unprecedented devastation. Political differences cannot get in the way. Americans need our help, and they need it now.
Here are some ways to help those reeling from Harvey, even if you live far from the storm.
When disaster strikes, count on the people of Connecticut to answer the call.

This closed door interview is only a partial step toward accountability for Donald Trump Jr. For a full, fair investigation, he must answer our questions in public, under oath before the American people about his disconcerting – legally problematic – activities. I will press for such testimony as soon as possible, along with other relevant witnesses.  Under Chairman Grassley and Ranking Member Feinstein’s leadership, the Senate Judiciary Committee’s investigation is moving forward, and I plan to rigorously question Donald Trump Jr. during his upcoming appearance before our panel.
Great to be back at Prides Corner Farms in Lebanon with Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue and many others. I look forward to collaborating on behalf of Connecticut's farmers.

The Attorney General is shamefully prejudging the courts and refusing to defend a lawful order of the President of the United States.  There is no such thing as an orderly wind-down of DACA. The threat of unprecedented, massive deportation will cause terror and anxiety for hundreds of thousands of Dreamers and their families. These young people came forward and shared their personal details - cell phone numbers, addresses, and tax information - on the promise that they would be permitted to stay here.  The chaos and confusion created by this announcement alone will not only disrupt and derail lives, it will be deeply destructive for our economy. It is creating an economic nightmare for employers and job creators who now have to replace a skilled and dedicated workforce. That’s why major business leaders and lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have urged against the Administration taking this sadly self-destructive action.  The President has completely abdicated leadership and offered no strategy for a solution. Now Congress must rise to the challenge and pass the Dream Act. This bipartisan legislation is more urgent and necessary than ever before.
I want every DREAMer in America to know this:  We see you.  We stand with you.  And we will fight for you with everything we've got.
We can curb the tragedy of child heatstroke deaths in hot cars. My legislation with U.S. Senator Al Franken would do just that.

There is no excuse for Equifax’s failure to strengthen its cyber-systems after suffering several previous breaches. The Federal Trade Commission must investigate this breach to assess whether Equifax did everything it could to secure all its systems given the sensitive nature of the consumer data it holds.  The massive data breach at Equifax is likely to impact millions of consumers – as many as half of all Americans – many of whom don’t even have a direct relationship with the company and may not know that their data has been compromised. That means all consumers need to be on high alert and vigilant about checking their credit, banking, and other accounts for potential misuse.  Congress must also enact data breach and security legislation immediately – only stiffer enforcement and stringent penalties will make sure companies are taking precautions to guard consumer data with the strongest available technology.

Sixteen years ago today, our nation was forever changed - a loss and hurt we will never forget.  We honor the American heroes who lost their lives that day, and we stand with the families of the fallen as one America - a united nation whose spirit will never be broken by evil.

I couldn’t be more appreciative of everyone who turned out for today’s emergency field hearing on immigration in New Haven.  The emotional and economic toll of President Trump’s cruel immigration policies was plain to see, as DREAMers and their loved ones came forward to share powerful accounts of the chaos that has gripped their families thanks to this administration’s callous actions.  It is my honor to amplify these courageous voices in Washington as we fight to pass the DREAM Act, protect DACA recipients from deportation, and enact immigration reform that delivers on America’s promise.

Access to affordable healthcare should be a clear right, not an exorbitant luxury. No one should endure sleepless nights terrified by a lack of healthcare because of how much they make or where they live.  That's why I’m proud to join my colleagues in the Senate and Americans around the country in supporting a system to give every family access to the security and stability of Medicare.

We've made tremendous strides thanks to the Affordable Care Act – but as I heard again and again from my constituents at field hearings across Connecticut, we must do more to lower costs, expand coverage, and protect patients and families. We have an obligation to deliver a healthcare system that allows everyone to access the care they need, regardless of where they live or how much they make.   That’s why I’m standing with Sen. Today is Constitution Day. On this date 230 years ago, our founders adopted the Constitution – a triumph that laid the foundation for American greatness and has inspired so many around the world to take up the fight for freedom.                                                                                               This is a day to reflect on and appreciate our remarkable heritage. But it is also a vital reminder of our ongoing obligation – here in the Constitution State and across this great nation – to preserve the gift passed down to us through the centuries.  In the spirit of our founders, I am hopeful we can recommit to the hard but essential work of forming a more perfect union – one rooted in cooperation, liberty, and respect for the rule of law.

The Senate Commerce Committee is holding a hearing on the Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act, my bipartisan bill with Senator Rob Portman to bring accountability to websites that facilitate this heinous crime.  Click here to watch today’s hearing once it begins at 10:30am: https://www.commerce.senate.gov/public/

Today I testified in support of the Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act, which I authored along with my colleague Sen. Portman.   Congress must act to hold websites that facilitate and support online sex trafficking accountable – and by amending Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, that is exactly what SESTA does. We have a social and moral obligation to end this shameful scourge and provide its victims – who in some cases were assaulted thousands of times – the day in court that they deserve.   I am so grateful to everyone who spoke out on behalf of this sorely needed reform. But I especially want to thank Yvonne Ambrose for bravely and powerfully recounting her daughter’s tragic fate at the hands of sex traffickers. Her experience, which never should have happened, is a sobering reminder of the consequences of inaction. It is my hope that today’s hearing will mark a turning point in this fight.

When I look at Graham/Cassidy, I can’t help but think of 7-year-old Conner Curran of Ridgefield, Connecticut.   Conner has Duchenne muscular dystrophy, an illness that slowly erodes motor functions. As it progresses, he will lose the ability to run, walk, or hug his parents goodnight. Unless a cure is found, it will one day take his life. But you’d never know it from the courage and strength he brings to each day, much like his incredible, hardworking family.   This summer, just before the last Republican scheme to gut the Affordable Care Act failed, Conner’s parents installed stair lifts in their home. You can imagine the infectious smile on Conner’s face as he tried it out – not fully grasping the reason for its necessity, but enjoying his newfound freedom to be a kid.   Conner’s mother wrote that their experience underscored just how vital Medicaid is to their family. As Conner gets older, he will need more and more help to maintain his quality of life. He will need a loving and compassionate healthcare system that will protect him when he is at his most vulnerable. That’s his only hope for a fair chance at life.  Graham/Cassidy, to put it mildly, deprives him of that chance.   I wonder if my Republican colleagues could look Conner or his parents in the eye and explain why protections for kids with preexisting conditions should be eviscerated – or why the funds they’ve proposed to replace Medicaid, the program that could one day make a life or death difference for him – should run out in 10 years. I wonder if they realize the havoc this bill would wreak on families facing similar worries in their own states.   This moment asks us to consider what kind of country we really are. I know we are better than a system that turns its back on kids like Conner and forces families to make an impossible choice between their children’s health and their finances.   I am ready to work in a bipartisan way on solutions to the healthcare problems facing our country. But I will not stand by and let Graham/Cassidy give Conner’s family – and countless others like them – more reason to worry. Not now, not ever.

The Republican plot to ram Graham/Cassidy through without a CBO score or regular order tells you everything you need to know about it. From community-based care to women's health and the opioid epidemic, its impact would be both far-reaching and devastating.  Americans deserve bipartisan healthcare fixes, not a slap in the face. This bill should not get one vote, let alone a majority.

The Republican tax plan is monstrously regressive – reform in name only, based on wildly unrealistic predictions of economic growth and job creation. For America's middle class it gives ‘mean’ new meaning. The sweeteners are crumbs and fig leaves – like a lump of sugar before the sucker punch, and tons of debt. This massive giveaway to special interests and the wealthiest is fundamentally unfair and fiscally irresponsible. Republicans’ hastily assembled would-be overhaul shifts the tax burden directly onto the backs of the middle class.   This proposal overwhelmingly favors the wealthiest Americans, while condemning the middle class to generations of debt repayment. It repeals the state and local tax deduction, devastating Connecticut families who save thousands each year and communities that benefit from the support it provides for local services. It eliminates the student loan interest deduction, throwing graduates already drowning in debt further under the bus. It even eliminates the adoption tax credit – targeting new families during a monumental transition. And it rewards companies for shifting their operations overseas, where their active income will no longer be taxed.  Even the credits Republicans claim benefit working families are paltry – the expanded child tax credit would be cancelled out for many by the elimination of personal exemptions. True tax reform would help all Americans get ahead. Until Republicans commit to a responsible, transparent, and bipartisan process – and pledge to protect the most vulnerable Americans – I’ll stand strong against this monstrous proposal.
