I’ve written to Secretary Mattis demanding answers and action to ensure consistent, timely reporting of this critical information.

During the last election cycle, 126 million Americans were exposed to false, misleading, and inflammatory posts generated by Russian agents right here on Facebook. These dangerous posts were meant to distort our election and divide our country. How can we know how to protect ourselves from this kind of interference in the future if we don’t even know if we were among those who were exposed? That’s why Facebook should let every one of its users know when, where, and how they may have been unwitting participants in Russia’s campaign to sow division and spread disinformation in the United States. Taking this step would help ensure that Facebook remains a vibrant community where users can exchange exciting ideas and real information.

On Veterans Day, we are reminded that America is the greatest nation on earth because generations of selfless patriots have sacrificed so much to safeguard our freedom, values, and way of life. The deportation stay for Cheshire’s Denada Rondos is a temporary victory for reason and justice. This relief will give the Rondos family the chance they deserve to pursue a fair and full hearing while remaining together in Connecticut, where they own and operate a business and contribute to their community.  This case is yet another tragic example of a deportation system that has lost all reason and rationality – needlessly breaking apart families and diverting federal resources from those who pose a true threat to public safety and national security.

In 2014, Connecticut mother Lori Jackson was gunned down by her estranged husband, who used a handgun he legally obtained while under a temporary restraining order. Had he tried to purchase that weapon just one day later, the temporary order would have become permanent – blocking the sale.  The law failed Lori when she needed it most.   Lori’s story is unfortunately just one example of the undeniable link between domestic violence and guns. Reports show that more than half of female homicide victims are killed by their intimate partners – and women are five times more likely to die as a result of domestic violence when there is a gun in the home.   These sobering statistics should motivate Congress to act, instead of continuing its complicity in this mass slaughter.    That’s why I’ve introduced the Lori Jackson Domestic Survivor Protection Act, a narrowly crafted measure to close the loophole that allows intimate partners to retain access to guns while under court restraining orders. With communities across America crying out for action on gun violence, it’s long past time Congress take this commonsense step to prevent future tragedies.

Today I’m proud to join my colleagues on both sides of the aisle in introducing the Fix NICS Act – a major milestone in combating gun violence.   Our commonsense bill will bolster public safety protections that could mean the difference between life and death. By incentivizing states and holding federal agencies accountable for building robust background check reporting systems, we can prevent gun sales to people who are a danger to themselves or others – including convicted domestic abusers. In so doing, we will begin to close the gaping loophole that allowed mass murderers in Sutherland Springs, Charleston, and Blacksburg to obtain the firearms used to commit their crimes.   While more must be done to defeat the scourge of gun violence, the Fix NICS Act represents a crucial step forward. I am grateful for the bipartisan coalition that has united behind this much-needed reform, and hopeful that the Senate will pass it and confront this crisis with action.
Our laws are only as effective as the judges who implement them. The far-right views of President Trump's nominees put our independent judiciary at risk.

The Fix NICS Act will help close potentially lethal reporting gaps, helping prevent gun sales to people who are a danger to themselves or others. I am hopeful that the powerful alliance united behind this legislation is a prelude to more bipartisan collaboration on gun violence prevention.

With the holiday season upon us, I urge everyone to read this new report before heading to the store. It could wind up saving you a trip to the emergency room.

This astoundingly reckless bill would require states to honor concealed carry permits issued by other states, even if those states have much looser – or outright nonexistent – permit standards. The result would essentially override Connecticut’s concealed carry laws, endangering law enforcement and putting public safety at risk.  As we near the fifth anniversary of the Sandy Hook tragedy and continue to grieve for the victims of Las Vegas and Sutherland Springs, I am disgusted that the House would prioritize the NRA’s wish list over commonsense gun safety reform. But I am especially outraged that House Republicans would couple this dangerous bill with the Fix NICS Act, my bipartisan reform to strengthen our background check system and keep firearms out of the wrong hands. No one should be fooled by this blatant attempt to sneak an extreme policy through Congress, and I will continue fighting alongside gun violence prevention advocates for a clean passage of the Fix NICS Act.  Americans deserve the security of an up-to-date background check system, without a poison pill like Concealed Carry Reciprocity.
